item.title: JPMorgan Is Committed to China for Long Term, Dimon Says
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. Chief Executive Officer Jamie Dimon said his firm is committed to long-term investment in China, despite frailties between the governments of the world’s two biggest economies.
item.dc:creator: Cathy Chan, Haslinda Amin

item.title: New Zealand Targets Investment With Budget Tax Incentive
item.description: New Zealand’s government is introducing a new tax incentive to increase business investment as it seeks to lift productivity and stoke economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: Dimon Warns of US Stagflation Risk, Says Fed Is Right to Hold
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. chief Jamie Dimon said he can’t rule out the US economy will fall into stagflation as the country faces huge risks from geopolitics, deficits and price pressures.
item.dc:creator: Ambereen Choudhury, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Jamie Dimon in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: How Low Will Australia’s Central Bank Go On Rates?
item.description: On this week’s Australia Podcast: Host Rebecca Jones speaks to Bloomberg Economics’ James McIntyre about the RBA’s rates experiment and whether it’s paid off.

media:content.media:description: Michele Bullock, governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), speaks during a news conference at the bank's head office in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, Apr. 1, 2025. Australia’s central bank kept its key interest rate unchanged, with Bullock unwilling to provide guidance on the May policy meeting as the board awaits more evidence that inflation is moving sustainably back to target in a world of mounting uncertainty.

item.title: Sri Lanka Unexpectedly Cuts Policy Rate to Bolster Recovery
item.description: Sri Lanka’s central bank unexpectedly cut its benchmark rate for the first time in six months, renewing its monetary policy easing cycle to bolster economic recovery.
item.dc:creator: Anusha Ondaatjie

media:content.media:description: A worker pulls a cart with bags of rice, flour, and garlic in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Tuesday, Nov. 28, 2023. Sri Lanka is scheduled to release consumer price index (CPI) figures on Nov. 30. Photographer: Thilina Kaluthotage/Bloomberg

item.title: BOJ Dove Noguchi Sees No Need to Change JGB Tapering Plan
item.description: A noted dove on the Bank of Japan’s policy board said there’s no need to make major changes to the bank’s plan for tapering bond purchases, a remark that comes a month before authorities unveil guidelines for bond buying in the period beyond April 2026.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Asahi Noguchi Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Singapore Flags Recession Risks After Strong Start to 2025
item.description: Singapore flagged the risk of a technical recession due to global tariff tensions even after its economy kick-started 2025 on a faster-than-expected note.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Bessent, Kato Confirm Existing FX Views, Avoid Talking Levels
item.description: US and Japanese finance chiefs confirmed existing currency views and did not discuss foreign exchange levels during a meeting in Canada, sending the yen briefly lower as markets wound back expectations for a more aggressive stance.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Indonesia Set for More Rate Cuts on Growth View, Analysts Say
item.description: An improving market sentiment will pave the way for Indonesia’s central bank to better balance its pro-growth stance with ensuring stability in the financial markets, according to analysts.
item.dc:creator: Prima Wirayani, Eduard Gismatullin

item.title: Ultra Rich Wanted More China Exposure Before Trade War, UBS Says
item.description: Many of the world’s richest family offices were planning to ramp up their investments in China despite the looming threat of a global trade war, according to a survey of UBS Group AG clients.
item.dc:creator: David Ramli, Yoojung Lee

item.title: Carney Says Canada, US Are in ‘High Level’ Talks on Golden Dome Defense System
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney confirmed Canada is considering joining the US in its “Golden Dome” missile defense project, but declined to put a price tag on it and said the talks are at an early stage.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt, Derek Decloet

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, during a news conference after a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. Carney's new cabinet includes a mix of familiar names and political rookies to carry out his ambitious economic agenda.

item.title: Why Trump Is Good News for Gulf Nations
item.description: On this week’s episode of Trumponomics, we look at how the US president’s recent trip to the region was a big win for Middle East oil states.
item.dc:creator: Sommer Saadi, Stephanie Flanders

media:content.media:description: RIYADH, SAUDI ARABIA - MAY 14: U.S. President Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman speak as they arrive during the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) Leaders’ Summit at The Ritz-Carlton on May 14, 2025 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The council addresses regional stability, defense cooperation, and energy policy among Gulf nations. Trump is on a multi-nation tour of the Gulf region focused on expanding economic ties and reinforcing security cooperation with key U.S. allies. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

item.title: Argentina’s Economy Grew Less Than Expected in March
item.description: Argentina’s economy grew less than expected in March as the country braced for a new program with the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at a wholesale supermarket in Buenos Aires.

item.title: ECB’s Escriva Says Unexpectedly Strong Euro Is Weighing on Inflation
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Jose Luis Escriva said the euro and energy prices have been weighing on consumer-price growth, while the fallout from US tariffs is more complicated to evaluate.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Jose Luis Escriva

item.title: G-7 Finance Ministers Aim to Avoid Public Spats With US Despite Trade Turmoil
item.description: Finance ministers who’ve gathered in Canada for a Group of Seven meeting this week face a difficult task — trying to find common ground on trade issues while avoiding public conflict with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Erik Hertzberg, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Tourists take photos with the Banff town sign, ahead of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada on May 20, 2025. Top finance leaders from the G7 nations gather in Canada starting Tuesday, with concerns including war in Ukraine at the fore while the advanced economies grapple with fallout from US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. (Photo by Cole Burston / AFP) (Photo by COLE BURSTON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: EU Sends New Trade Proposal to US in Step to Secure Deal
item.description: The European Union has shared a revised trade proposal with the US, as it aims to inject momentum in talks with President Donald Trump’s administration amid lingering skepticism that a transatlantic deal can be reached.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Containers at Trieste Port in Trieste, Italy.

item.title: France’s Lombard Eyes Progress With US at G-7, Even Without a Communique
item.description: France’s finance chief Eric Lombard said the Group of Seven can make progress on resolving differences with the US on divisive issues including trade, even if officials meeting over the next two days fail to deliver a final communique.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: France’s finance chief Eric Lombard, right, meets Canadian Finance Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne during the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors’ Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada, on May 21.

item.title: South Africa Central Bank Deputy Governor Says Inflation Goal Is Too Wide
item.description: South African Reserve Bank Deputy Governor Fundi Tshazibana said there is broad agreement that the country’s 3% to 6% inflation target range is too wide.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: Fundi Tshazibana

item.title: Milei Stumbles in Bid to Unchain Farmers as Soy Tax Break Ends
item.description: President Javier Milei’s vow to unleash Argentina’s beleaguered farmers is faltering after a decision to raise taxes on soy exports by about seven percentage points.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Gilbert

media:content.media:description: A combine harvester cuts through a field of soybean plants in San Jose de la Esquina, Argentina.

item.title: Meloni Looks to Moody’s to End Italy’s Near-Junk Status
item.description: Italy is just two days away from the chance to start shaking off the near-junk status that has hung over Giorgia Meloni’s premiership.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: Giorgia Meloni Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Iceland Cuts Rate and Signals More Moves Hinge on Inflation
item.description: Iceland’s central bank lowered its key interest rate for a fifth straight meeting, and signaled further reductions depend on inflation moving closer to its target.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

media:content.media:description: The logo of Sedlabanki Islands, Iceland's central bank in Reykjavik.

item.title: Johnson Says Deal Reached on Raising SALT Cap to $40,000
item.description: House Speaker Mike Johnson said Republicans have reached an agreement to increase the state and local tax deduction to $40,000, suggesting a resolution to one of the final issues holding up President Donald Trump’s economic bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Nacha Cattan

media:content.media:description: House Speaker Mike Johnson

item.title: Half of Turkish Firms in Red as Tight Monetary Policy Bites
item.description: Turkish companies that once backed the central bank’s return to orthodox monetary policy are now reporting widespread losses, as borrowing costs near 50% and fears of a hard landing grow.
item.dc:creator: Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers in the International Finance Center, including the Turkish central bank, center, in Istanbul.

item.title: Winners and Losers in South Africa’s Latest Budget Attempt
item.description: South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana presented a third version of the national budget to lawmakers in Cape Town on Wednesday after months of wrangling over tax increases.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Street vendors at an outdoor market in Pretoria, South Africa. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Highlights of South African Finance Minister’s Reworked Budget
item.description: Below are the highlights of South Africa’s third iteration of the 2025 budget announced by Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana in Cape Town on Wednesday, after two previous versions were withdrawn because of disagreements within the governing coalition over taxes.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: Over the next three years, 1.03 trillion rand will be allocated to public infrastructure. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Milei’s Cuts Have Argentines Driving New Cars With Paper License Plates
item.description: Mariela Mailhe sells imported cars in one of Argentina’s flashiest neighborhoods. They come with electronically adjustable leather seats and panoramic sunroofs, but thanks in part to Javier Milei’s austerity campaign they roll off the lot with paper license plates.
item.dc:creator: Ignacio Olivera Doll

media:content.media:description: Traffic on the General Paz avenue in Buenos Aires. Photographer: Luis Robayo/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Mnuchin Flags US Budget Deficit as Bigger Worry Than Trade Gap
item.description: Former United States Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said he’s more alarmed by the country’s growing budget deficit than its trade imbalances, and urged Washington to prioritize fiscal repair.
item.dc:creator: Anto Antony

media:content.media:description: Steven Mnuchin Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Guindos Sees Price Target Hit Sooner Rather Than Later
item.description: The European Central Bank isn’t far from achieving its 2% inflation target, helped by a stronger euro and falling energy costs, according to Vice President Luis de Guindos.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers

item.title: Trump Jr. Says ‘Maybe One Day’ He’ll Look to Succeed His Father
item.description: Donald Trump Jr. hinted that he may run for political office and try to succeed his father as US president.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace, Beril Akman, Zainab Fattah, Joumanna Bercetche

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Exporters Rush to Meet US Import Demand
item.description: The US-China trade truce last week sparked an immediate revival along one of the world’s most important trade routes, and Guangdong-based supply chain manager Chen Lei was at the forefront.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva
